questions.question: Can you describe your First Nation's governance structure and forest management authority?
questions.why: SFI needs to verify you're a First Nation/Indigenous org with decision-making responsibilities for forests in Canada
questions.help_text: Example: We are [Band Name] with a Community Forest Agreement covering 15,000 hectares. Our Lands Department has authority over forest management decisions as delegated by Chief and Council.

questions.question: Do you have a Band Council Resolution (BCR) supporting this project?
questions.why: BCR is required for submission - this tells us if you're ready to submit or need to schedule this
questions.help_text: If not yet: When is your next Chief & Council meeting? BCRs typically take 2-4 weeks.
examples: Yes - BCR passed on [Date]
Not yet - Next C&C meeting is [Date], will request BCR then
In progress - Draft BCR prepared, awaiting next meeting on [Date]

questions.question: Do you have a letter of support from Chief & Council ready?
questions.why: Required supporting document - checks if you have this or need to obtain it
examples: Yes - letter signed and ready
Draft prepared - awaiting Chief's signature
Not yet - will request after BCR is approved

questions.question: What is the forest classification and age class of your project area?
questions.why: SFI wants to understand the forest type and stand maturity to assess project approach
questions.help_text: Include: biogeoclimatic zone, dominant tree species, age class range
examples: Coastal Western Hemlock (CWH), 60-100 year old second growth with scattered old-growth legacy trees
Interior Douglas-fir (IDF), young forest 20-40 years with mixed species composition

smart_default.Barkley Sound: Coastal Western Hemlock with cedar component
smart_default.Interior: Check if IDF, ICH, or SBS biogeoclimatic zone

questions.question: Can you provide specific location details (geographic coordinates, watershed name, or land designation)?
questions.why: SFI requires specific project location in the application
questions.help_text: Examples: GPS coordinates, watershed name, TFL/Community Forest name, traditional territory description

questions.question: What specific on-the-ground activities will you implement? Be detailed about methods.
questions.why: SFI requires detailed description of implementation activities and methodologies
questions.help_text: Go beyond general categories - describe specific techniques, equipment, approaches
examples: Site preparation: Manual brushing (no herbicides) followed by cedar planting at 1,200 stems/ha density. Retention harvest: 15-20% basal area retention focused on legacy cedar and culturally modified trees
Assisted migration trials: Planting Douglas-fir seed from 2 climate zones warmer (400m elevation equivalent) across 50-hectare test sites with monitoring plots

questions.question: Your project covers {project_size} hectares. How could this methodology be scaled to 20,000+ hectares or replicated elsewhere?
questions.why: SFI prioritizes projects relevant for large forest managers - they want to see broader applicability
questions.help_text: Focus on: methodology transferability, cost-effectiveness at scale, other Nations/areas that could use this approach
examples: Our TK + LiDAR protocol for cedar site identification can be applied by any Nation with forest tenure and access to provincial LiDAR data
Approach designed as modular framework - restoration prescriptions can be adapted to different biogeoclimatic zones across coastal BC

questions.question: What are your specific, measurable outcomes? (Provide numbers: hectares, trees, jobs, training participants, etc.)
questions.why: SFI wants to see concrete deliverables - be specific with quantities
questions.help_text: Quantify everything you can: area treated, trees planted, people employed, sites protected, etc.
examples: • 500 hectares restored • 60,000 cedar seedlings planted • 3 full-time positions (6 months each) • 5 youth trained in forestry practices • 12 culturally significant sites protected
• 1,200 hectares under retention harvest • 4 employment positions • 2 elders engaged as advisors • 20 community members participate in field sessions

questions.question: What specific cultural and socioeconomic benefits will this project provide to your community?
questions.why: ECCC funding requires demonstration of cultural value enhancement - this is a key selection criterion
examples: Enhanced access to traditional medicines (devil's club, cedar bark, berries)
Youth employment and forestry training - minimum 3 positions
Protection of ceremonial bark-harvesting sites
Strengthening intergenerational traditional knowledge transmission

questions.question: What measurable climate benefits will this project provide (emissions reduction, carbon storage, or climate adaptation)?
questions.why: Climate benefits are required for ECCC funding - be specific about mechanism
examples: Retention harvest reduces emissions vs. clearcut by avoiding slash burning of 500 tonnes biomass
Climate-adapted species selection increases forest resilience - planting drought-tolerant provenances reduces mortality risk under +2°C scenarios
Structural diversification creates fire-resilient stands through 20% retention and species mixing

questions.question: Who are the key team members and what relevant experience do they bring?
questions.why: SFI evaluates 'demonstrated knowledge, experience, and expertise'
questions.format: List 2-4 people with: Name, Role, 1-2 sentence background
questions.help_text: Include: RPF/forestry professionals, elders/knowledge keepers, project managers

questions.question: How will you monitor and measure project success? What data will you collect?
questions.why: SFI evaluates 'commitment to appropriate measurement and monitoring'
questions.help_text: Describe: baseline data collection, ongoing monitoring methods, success indicators, photo points, etc.
examples: Baseline: Pre-treatment forest inventory, site photos. Ongoing: Annual survival surveys, photo point monitoring. Success metrics: >80% seedling survival, increased structural diversity indices
Establish 10 permanent monitoring plots, annual measurements of tree growth/survival, photo documentation, community satisfaction surveys

questions.question: Do you have a methodology to quantify carbon or GHG benefits?
questions.why: Not required, but projects with quantification methods receive priority
examples: Will use BC Ministry TIPSY models to compare carbon storage trajectories between retention and clearcut scenarios
Partnering with UBC Faculty of Forestry for carbon assessment using CBM-CFS3 model
Working with RPF to estimate avoided emissions from eliminating slash burning (500 tonnes biomass)

questions.question: Will this be a 1-year or 2-year project? What are your key milestones?
questions.why: SFI needs timeline - funds must be spent by March 31, 2027
questions.help_text: Maximum 2 years. Include major milestones like planning, field work, reporting
examples: 2-year: Year 1 - site prep, initial planting (300ha), interim report. Year 2 - expansion planting (200ha), monitoring, final report
1-year: Months 1-3 planning/procurement, Months 4-8 implementation, Months 9-12 monitoring/reporting

questions.question: Please provide a budget breakdown by category (implementation, staff, community engagement, admin)
questions.why: SFI requires budget with milestones. Admin max 10%, staff/travel <40%
questions.help_text: Break down by: field work/operations (should be 60%+), project management/staff, community engagement, travel/training, admin
examples: Implementation 65% ($195K: planting, equipment, contractors), Staff 25% ($75K: project manager, technicians), Community 7% ($21K: elder honoraria, workshops), Admin 3% ($9K)
Year 1: $140K (site prep $80K, staff $45K, engagement $10K, admin $5K). Year 2: $160K (planting $100K, monitoring $35K, reporting $20K, admin $5K)

questions.question: Are you partnering with any forest companies, research institutions, or other organizations? If yes, what is their role?
questions.why: SFI encourages partnerships with forest management companies - collaboration strengthens applications
examples: Partnership with Mosaic Forest Management who manages adjacent TFL - providing technical support, equipment rental at cost, and RPF expertise
Collaborating with UBC Faculty of Forestry on monitoring protocols and carbon assessment methodology
Working with neighboring Huu-ay-aht First Nation who completed similar cedar project - sharing lessons learned
questions.competitive_advantage: +15% selection priority for forest company partnerships
questions.help_text: Partnerships demonstrate collaboration capacity and increase project feasibility

questions.question: Do you have any matching funding or in-kind contributions? If yes, describe.
questions.why: Matching contributions are valued in selection criteria - shows broader support
examples: In-kind: Community volunteer hours ($15K value), equipment use from forestry contractor ($8K)
Cash match: $50K from own-source revenue, $30K from [other funder]
In-kind: RPF technical services donated by partner company ($20K value)

questions.question: Have you identified what permits or authorizations you'll need? Do you have them or know how to get them?
questions.why: Permits can cause major delays - this checks if you've thought through regulatory requirements
questions.help_text: Common needs: forestry permits, archaeological overview, species at risk assessment, environmental permits
examples: Will need: Cutting permit (have RPF preparing), Archaeological overview (scheduled for January). No species at risk in project area (confirmed with biologist)
Already have: Forestry Development Unit approval. Will coordinate with existing TFL permit processes

questions.question: Have you consulted with your community about this project? What was the response?
questions.why: Community support is essential for success and often required for Chief & Council approval
questions.help_text: Describe any community meetings, surveys, or consultations you've done
examples: Presented at community meeting on Oct 15 - strong support from 35 members. Elders particularly interested in cultural site protection component
Conducted survey with 50 members - 90% support restoration priorities. Follow-up session planned for December

questions.question: Can you realistically complete this project and spend all funds by March 31, 2027? Walk through your timeline.
questions.why: This is a hard deadline - SFI needs to know you can execute in time
questions.help_text: Consider: permitting time, Chief & Council approval, seasonal windows for field work, procurement, hiring
examples: Yes - Application Jan 2025, approval Feb 2025, field work Apr-Oct 2025 and 2026 (within planting windows), final report Q1 2027
Tight but doable - Need BCR by Feb, permits by March, begin field work May to maximize 2025 growing season

questions.question: Do you have an RPF (Registered Professional Forester) involved or lined up for this project?
questions.why: Technical forestry work often requires RPF oversight - confirms you have professional capacity
examples: Yes - Sarah Johnson RPF is our Lands Manager and will oversee all forestry activities
Will hire - We've identified 2 local RPFs interested in contract work
Partnership - Mosaic Forest Management will provide RPF support as in-kind contribution

questions.question: Has your organization successfully managed grants before? Any relevant examples?
questions.why: Demonstrates grant management capacity - reassures funder you can deliver
examples: Yes - Successfully completed $180K FWCP watershed restoration grant (2022-2024), delivered on time and budget
Multiple grants: BCSRIF ($150K), Habitat Conservation Trust ($75K), all with strong final reports
First major grant - but Lands Manager has 10 years experience with federal grants at previous Nation

questions.question: How will you share learnings from this project with other First Nations or forest managers?
questions.why: SFI values knowledge sharing and broader impact beyond single project
questions.help_text: Think about: presentations at conferences, case studies, workshops, field tours, publications
examples: Will present results at SILVA21 annual meeting, host field tour for neighboring Nations, publish case study on our website
Committed to developing a protocol guide for other coastal Nations, presenting at BC First Nations Forestry Council annual gathering

questions.question: What measurable climate benefits will this project provide (emissions reduction, carbon storage, or climate adaptation)?
questions.why: Climate benefits are required for ECCC funding - be specific about mechanism
examples: Retention harvest reduces emissions vs. clearcut by avoiding slash burning of estimated 500 tonnes biomass (250 tonnes CO2e)
Climate-adapted species selection increases forest resilience - planting drought-tolerant provenances reduces mortality risk under +2°C scenarios by estimated 30%
Structural diversification creates fire-resilient stands through 20% retention and species mixing, reducing catastrophic fire risk

questions.question: Who are the key team members and what relevant experience do they bring?
questions.why: SFI evaluates 'demonstrated knowledge, experience, and expertise'
questions.format: List 2-4 people with: Name, Role, 1-2 sentence background
questions.help_text: Include: RPF/forestry professionals, elders/knowledge keepers, project managers

questions.question: How will you monitor and measure project success? What data will you collect?
questions.why: SFI evaluates 'commitment to appropriate measurement and monitoring'
questions.help_text: Describe: baseline data collection, ongoing monitoring methods, success indicators, photo points
examples: Baseline: Pre-treatment forest inventory, site photos, cultural site mapping. Ongoing: Annual survival surveys at 20 monitoring plots, photo point monitoring (50 locations), growth measurements. Success metrics: >80% seedling survival year 1, >70% year 3
Establish 10 permanent monitoring plots (20x20m), measure tree growth/survival annually, document cultural plant recovery, photo documentation, elder assessment of cultural access improvements

questions.question: Do you have a methodology to quantify carbon or GHG benefits?
questions.why: Not required, but projects with quantification methods receive priority
examples: Will use BC Ministry TIPSY models to compare carbon storage trajectories between retention and clearcut scenarios over 100-year rotation
Partnering with UBC Faculty of Forestry for carbon assessment using CBM-CFS3 model - will quantify avoided emissions from reduced slash burning
Working with RPF to estimate: (1) avoided emissions from no slash burn = 250 tonnes CO2e, (2) additional carbon in retained trees = 1,200 tonnes CO2 over 50 years

questions.question: Will this be a 1-year or 2-year project? What are your key milestones by quarter?
questions.why: SFI needs detailed timeline - funds must be spent by March 31, 2027
questions.help_text: Be specific about timing - when will each major activity happen?
examples: 2-year: Year 1 Q1-Q2: Planning, procurement, BCR/permits. Q3-Q4: Site prep, initial planting 300ha. Year 2 Q1-Q2: Expansion 200ha. Q3-Q4: Monitoring, final report
1-year: Q1 (Jan-Mar): Finalize planning, hire crew. Q2 (Apr-Jun): Implementation phase 1. Q3 (Jul-Sep): Implementation phase 2. Q4 (Oct-Dec): Monitoring, reporting

questions.question: Do you have a detailed budget spreadsheet prepared with line items and costs?
questions.why: Checks if budget is actually ready or still rough estimates
examples: Yes - Excel spreadsheet with all line items, quotes from contractors, hourly rates for staff
Mostly complete - Have contractor quotes and staff costs, need to finalize equipment rental rates
Not yet - Have overall categories and estimates, need to get formal quotes

questions.question: If you have partners, do you have commitment letters from them ready or in progress?
questions.why: Partner letters strengthen applications significantly - checks actual status
examples: Yes - Letter of support from Mosaic Forest Management already signed
In progress - Drafted letter, awaiting signature from UBC professor
Not yet - Will request letters once BCR is approved

questions.question: Who will be responsible for interim and final reporting to SFI? Do they have capacity?
questions.why: Reporting is mandatory - confirms you've thought about this commitment
examples: Project Manager will lead reporting with support from RPF for technical sections - both have experience with government grant reporting
Lands Manager will coordinate - has completed 5+ final reports for federal grants
Will hire part-time report writer (included in budget) to support Project Coordinator

questions.question: Are you open to collaborating with SFI staff and sharing data/lessons learned throughout the project?
questions.why: SFI requires collaborative engagement - they want active partners, not just grant recipients
examples: Yes - Welcome SFI site visits, happy to share monitoring data, interested in presenting at SFI workshops
Absolutely - Excited to contribute to broader climate smart forestry knowledge base, open to adaptive management based on SFI feedback

critical.where_to_find: Community Forest Agreement or tenure documents

strengthen.item: Partnership letters from forest companies or institutions

strengthen.how_to_get: Meeting notes, survey results, photos from community sessions
